understanding.p: A topic set is a collection of related topics that follow the same schema. Multiple topic sets can use the same schema. By default, individual topics in the topic set are presented in alphabetical order under the topic set.
Typically, a documentation set includes a topic set and the topic set appears in the table of contents of a documentation set that includes it.

planning-question.planning-question-title: Do I neeed to create a new topic set?

planning-question-body.p: You could have a single topic set that contains all the topics; however, you typically want to use a topic set to group topics with related content and present the topic sets in a specific order in the table of contents. You may also want topics to follow different schemas. Grouping topics into different topic sets enables you to reuse topics in different topic sets and multiple documentation sets can reuse topic sets.

how-to-answer-body.p: If you want to do any of the following, you need a new topic set:

li.p: Introduce a new schema—the topics in a topic set follow the same schema
Add new entry to the table of contents—there is one entry for each topic set in the table of contents

doing.p: Normally, you define the elements specific to your topic set in a separate configuration file and include the main configuration file. This enables you to import common values and override the elements that are specific to your topic set, which maximizes reuse. If you use a separate configuration file, you must include the spfe element.
You need the following elements for a topic set:

li.p: /spfe/topic-set-id: A unqiue value that identifies the topic set. The build system uses the value to create file names and it must be a valid file name in the operating system that runs the build system. If you define a /spfe/topic-set-id, the output for the topic set is stored in a subdirectory with the same name under the/spfe/build/build-directory.

/spfe/topic-set-type: The value determines the location of the topic set in the table of contents and it must match one of the entries in the /spfe/doc-set/topic-set-type-order. The elements are codependent; they must both be defined or omitted from the configuration file.

/spfe/sources: The list of directories that contain the contents of the topics. Contents include text, graphics, and information from outside sources that make up the topic content. While this element is optional, without it, the topic set has no content.
/spfe/output-format: The document formats that you want the build system to create for this topic-set.

/spfe/build/build-rules: The name of the ANT build rules file uses the elements in the configuration files to specify which build script files are called and the order in which to run the scripts. Each topic set can use a different rules file.

/spfe/build/build-directory: Directory location used to store temporary files and the output generated during the build process. If none of the configuration files specify this element, the build system appends the value of /spfe/doc-set/@id to the value of the SPFE_BUILD_DIR environment variable.
/spfe/build/output-directory: Path to the folder that contains the output files for the topic-set. If you do not specify a value, the default EPPO build scripts fail.

/spfe/deployment/output-path: The path to the folder that contains the document output. The build system appends the value of this element to /spfe/build/output-directory. If you do not specify a value for this element, the directory /spfe/build/output-directory contains the topic set output files. If topic sets have topic files with the same name (for example, index.html), the files are overwritten. It is a good practice to use a separate directory for the output of each topic set.

/spfe/scripts: The list of scripts to process the topic set. If you use an existing schema, you can reuse the existing scripts. If you specify scripts that all topic-sets use in the main configuration file, you only need to specify topic set specific scripts here.

doing.p: If you want content at the top level folder, you need an index topic.

When you build the documentation set that includes your topic set, if your topic set appears in the table of contents in the order you specified, you have successfully added your topic set to the document.
